claims.text: Human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world.
claims.context: General statement about climate change causes.

claims.text: The main cause of climate change is the greenhouse effect.
Gases like carbon dioxide and methane trap heat in the atmosphere.
Human activities have increased CO2 in the atmosphere by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution.
Atmospheric carbon dioxide hasn't reached today's levels in hundreds of thousands of years.
Ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting, causing sea levels to rise.
claims.context: Impact of climate change on ice sheets.

claims.text: Warmer temperatures make weather more extreme, leading to intense storms and floods.
claims.context: Consequences of climate change on weather.

claims.text: Climate change can directly affect people's physical health by increasing smog levels.
Exposure to higher levels of smog can cause health problems such as asthma and heart disease.
claims.context: Specific health risks associated with smog.

claims.text: Replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources can help combat climate change.

claim_reports.claim_text: Human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the Earth's temperature and changing the world, with multiple high-reliability sources attributing the observed global warming trend primarily to greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel combustion and deforestation.

supports.title: Are humans causing or contributing to global warming? - Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the Earth's temperature by significantly increasing greenhouse gas emissions, particularly through the burning of fossil fuels and other industrial processes. It explains how these gases trap heat in the atmosphere, thereby amplifying the natural greenhouse effect.
supports.snippet: Yes, by increasing the abundance of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, human activities are amplifying Earth's natural greenhouse effect.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly states that human activities, particularly through the emission of greenhouse gases, are the primary cause of the global warming trend observed since the mid-20th century, confirming the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world.
supports.snippet: Human activities, principally through emissions of greenhouse gases, have unequivocally caused global warming, with global surface temperature ...

supports.title: The Causes of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world, as it attributes the observed global warming trend since the mid-20th century to human expansion of the greenhouse effect, primarily through the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation.
supports.snippet: Human Activity Is the Cause of Increased Greenhouse Gas Concentrations. Over the last century, burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil has ...

supports.title: Human Impacts on the Environment: A Focus on Climate Change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world, as it attributes the observed global warming trend since the mid-20th century to human actions such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, which increase greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere.
supports.snippet: Human activities are driving large scale changes in terrestrial and aquatic environments through pollution, water withdrawals, the hunting and harvesting of ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The main cause of climate change is the greenhouse effect.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the greenhouse effect is the main cause of climate change, with multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and NRDC, explaining how greenhouse gases from fossil fuel emissions trap heat in the atmosphere, leading to global warming.

supports.title: What is the greenhouse effect? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that greenhouse gases, primarily from fossil fuel emissions, trap heat in the atmosphere, leading to global warming and climate change, which supports the claim that the greenhouse effect is a main cause of climate change.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect is the process through which heat is trapped near Earth's surface by substances known as 'greenhouse gases.

supports.title: Greenhouse Effect 101 - NRDC
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that fossil fuels are the largest contributors to greenhouse gas emissions, which trap heat in the atmosphere, leading to climate change. This supports the claim that the greenhouse effect is a main cause of climate change.
supports.snippet: These emissions, made up mostly of carbon dioxide and methane, stem primarily from burning natural gas and oil for heating and cooking, though ...

supports.title: Review Greenhouse gases emissions and global climate change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how the increase in greenhouse gas concentrations due to human activity enhances the greenhouse effect, which is a primary driver of global warming and climate change.
supports.snippet: The increase in GHG concentrations as a result of human activity enhances the greenhouse effect, leading to global warming. This process ...

supports.title: Causes and Effects of Climate Change | United Nations
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that greenhouse gas emissions, primarily from fossil fuels, trap the sun's heat, leading to global warming and climate change, which supports the claim that the greenhouse effect is a main cause of climate change.
supports.snippet: Fossil fuels – coal, oil and gas – are by far the largest contributor to global climate change, accounting for around 68 per cent of global greenhouse gas ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Human activities have increased CO2 in the atmosphere by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that human activities have significantly increased atmospheric CO2 levels by more than 50% since the Industrial Revolution, supporting the claim that CO2 has risen by more than a third.

supports.title: Climate change: atmospheric carbon dioxide
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that atmospheric carbon dioxide levels have increased significantly due to human activities, specifically fossil fuel burning, which has raised CO2 levels by more than 50% since the Industrial Revolution.
supports.snippet: Atmospheric carbon dioxide is now 50 percent higher than it was before the Industrial Revolution. The annual rate of increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide over ...

supports.title: Evidence - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that human activities have significantly increased atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, with current rates of increase being about 250 times faster than natural sources after the last Ice Age. This aligns with the claim that CO2 levels have risen by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution.
supports.snippet: There is unequivocal evidence that Earth is warming at an unprecedented rate. Human activity is the principal cause.

supports.title: Carbon dioxide now more than 50% higher than pre-industrial levels
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that atmospheric carbon dioxide levels have increased significantly since the Industrial Revolution, with current levels being more than 50% higher than pre-industrial levels of around 280 ppm, confirming the claim that human activities have increased CO2 in the atmosphere by more than a third.
supports.snippet: Prior to the Industrial Revolution, CO2 levels were consistently around 280 ppm for almost 6,000 years of human civilization. Since then, humans ...

supports.title: How have CO2 levels changed since the industrial revolution?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that atmospheric carbon dioxide levels have increased significantly due to human activities, specifically the burning of fossil fuels since the Industrial Revolution, with current levels being about 50% higher than pre-industrial levels.
supports.snippet: Carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere is now reaching levels 50% higher than when humanity began large-scale burning of fossil fuels during the industrial ...

supports.title: The History of Carbon Dioxide Emissions | World Resources Institute
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that human activities have significantly increased carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere, with current emissions being about 250 times faster than natural sources after the last Ice Age. This increase in CO2 is a primary driver of the current warming trend since the Industrial Revolution.
supports.snippet: Carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from human activities are now higher than at any point in our history. In fact, recent data reveals that global ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Warmer temperatures make weather more extreme, leading to intense storms and floods.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources, including a study from the National Institutes of Health and USGS, confirm that warmer temperatures are linked to more intense storms and flooding due to increased water vapor in the atmosphere. This is further supported by empirical data on tropical cyclones and rainfall patterns.

supports.title: Extreme Weather and Climate Change: Population Health and ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that warmer temperatures are linked to more intense storms and floods, as rising sea temperatures increase water vapor in the atmosphere, fueling hurricanes and heavy rainfall. This connection is supported by empirical data showing changes in tropical cyclone behavior and increased rainfall associated with these storms.
supports.snippet: Extreme weather and climate events, such as heat waves, cyclones, and floods, are an expression of climate variability. These events and events influenced ...

supports.title: How can climate change affect natural disasters? - USGS.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that warmer temperatures contribute to more intense storms and flooding, as rising sea temperatures increase water vapor in the atmosphere, fueling hurricanes and torrential rain, which leads to more severe weather events.
supports.snippet: With increasing global surface temperatures the possibility of more droughts and increased intensity of storms will likely occur.

supports.title: Extreme Weather and Climate Change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that warmer temperatures contribute to more intense storms and flooding by increasing the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere, which fuels hurricanes and torrential rain. This aligns with the claim that warmer temperatures lead to more extreme weather events.
supports.snippet: Climate change is expected to worsen the frequency, intensity, and impacts of some types of extreme weather events.

unclear.evidence_summary: Wintry weather is sweeping across parts of the United States this weekend, bringing with it brutally low temperatures.
unclear.snippet: Wintry weather is sweeping across parts of the United States this weekend, bringing with it brutally low temperatures.

claim_reports.claim_text: Exposure to higher levels of smog can cause health problems such as asthma and heart disease.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that exposure to higher levels of smog is linked to health problems such as asthma and heart disease. Multiple high-reliability sources, including the Harvard study and the American Lung Association, confirm this association, highlighting the risks posed by fine particulate matter and ozone.

supports.title: The dangers of air pollution for heart health
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that exposure to higher levels of smog, specifically fine particulate matter (PM2.5), is linked to serious health problems, including asthma and heart disease. Studies cited in the article indicate a clear association between air pollution and cardiovascular issues, with significant mortality rates attributed to cardiovascular-related diseases due to air pollution exposure.
supports.snippet: Although many are aware of air pollution's link to respiratory diseases, its impact on the cardiovascular system is less well-known.

supports.title: Asthma and Heart Disease - AirNow.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that exposure to smog, particularly ozone, is harmful to health, causing respiratory issues and exacerbating conditions like asthma and heart disease, especially in vulnerable populations.
supports.snippet: Studies also show that air pollution can trigger heart attacks, stroke, and irregular heart rhythms—especially in people who are already at risk for these ...

supports.title: Health Impact of Air Pollution - American Lung Association
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that exposure to air pollution, including smog, significantly increases the risk of health issues such as asthma and heart disease, confirming the claim.
supports.snippet: The increased risk was primarily associated with death from cardiovascular and respiratory causes, including heart disease, stroke, influenza, and pneumonia.

claim_reports.claim_text: Replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources can help combat climate change.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources can help combat climate change. Key sources, including the IRENA article and NRDC report, emphasize that transitioning to renewables is essential for reducing carbon emissions and achieving significant reductions in greenhouse gases.

supports.title: How to Transform Energy System And Reduce Carbon Emissions
supports.evidence_summary: The article emphasizes that transitioning from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources is essential for reducing carbon emissions and combating climate change, stating that renewables could account for over 90% of global electricity generation by 2050.
supports.snippet: Renewables and energy efficiency, boosted by substantial electrification, can provide over 90% of the necessary reductions in energy-related carbon emissions.

supports.title: Renewable Energy Is Key to Fighting Climate Change - NRDC
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources can help combat climate change, highlighting renewable energy as an effective tool in reducing emissions and providing economic and health benefits.
supports.snippet: Renewable energy is one of the most effective tools we have in the fight against climate change, and there is every reason to believe it will succeed.

supports.title: Replacing fossil fuel-based power plants with renewables to meet ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources can help combat climate change, highlighting that a sustainable energy transition is essential for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.
supports.snippet: They measured GHG emissions. The results revealed a 36.9 % reduction in emissions (from 0.484 Gt CO2eq to 0.305 Gt CO2eq).

claim_reports.claim_text: Ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting, causing sea levels to rise.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that the melting of ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica is contributing to rising sea levels, with projections indicating a potential rise of up to 23 feet if the Greenland ice sheet were to melt completely.

supports.title: Greenland's Ice Is Melting - UCAR Center for Science Education
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ice sheets in Greenland are melting due to global warming, which is a significant predictor of rising sea levels. It states that if the Greenland ice sheet melts entirely, global sea levels could rise by 20 feet, supporting the claim about the impact of melting ice sheets on sea levels.
supports.snippet: Earth's warming climate means that overall Greenland loses more ice than it gains each year. Warmer temperatures mean more melt days. During summer, ...

supports.title: Six ways loss of Arctic ice impacts everyone - World Wildlife Fund
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the melting of polar ice caps, including the Greenland ice sheet, and its direct impact on rising sea levels, indicating that if the Greenland ice sheet melts entirely, global sea levels could rise by 20 feet.
supports.snippet: Discover six ways Arctic ice loss affects the planet, including rising sea levels, weather changes, and impacts on wildlife and communities.

claim_reports.claim_text: Atmospheric carbon dioxide hasn't reached today's levels in hundreds of thousands of years.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents mixed signals regarding atmospheric CO2 levels. While it is noted that CO2 levels have increased significantly from about 280 ppm in the late 1700s to around 420 ppm today, the historical context indicates that CO2 levels naturally cycled between 200 ppm and 250 ppm over the past million years. This suggests that while current levels are unprecedented in recent history, the claim about hundreds of thousands of years lacks clarity due to the varying timeframes discussed.

unclear.snippet: Which does not change the simple facts that atmospheric CO2 was naturally cycling from about 200ppm to about 250ppm for the past million years.

transcript_data.text: human activities from pollution to overpopulation are driving up the earth's temperature and fundamentally changing the world around us the main cause is a phenomenon known as the greenhouse effect gases in the atmosphere such as water vapor carbon dioxide methane nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons let the sun's light in but keep some of the heat from escaping like the glass walls of a greenhouse the more greenhouse gases in the atmosphere the more heat gets trapped strengthening the greenhouse effect and increasing the earth's temperature human activities like the burning of fossil fuels have increased the amount of co2 in the atmosphere by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution the rapid increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere has warmed the planet at an alarming rate while Earth's climate has fluctuated in the past atmospheric carbon dioxide hasn't reached today's levels in hundreds of thousands of years climate change has consequences for our oceans our weather our food sources and our health ice sheets such as Greenland and Antarctica are melting the extra water that was once held in glaciers causes sea levels to rise and spills out of the oceans flooding coastal regions warmer temperatures also make weather more extreme this means not only more intense major storms floods and heavy snowfall but also longer and more frequent droughts these changes in weather pose challenges growing crops becomes more difficult the areas where plants and animals can live shift and water supplies are diminished in addition to creating new agricultural challenges climate change can directly affect people's physical health in urban areas the warmer atmosphere creates an environment that traps and increases the amount of smog this is because smog contains ozone particles which increase rapidly at higher temperatures exposure to higher levels of smog can cause health problems such as asthma heart disease and lung cancer while the rapid rate of climate change is caused by humans humans are also the ones who can combat it if we work to replace fossil fuels with renewable energy sources like solar and wind which don't produce greenhouse gas emissions we might still be able to prevent some of the worst effects of climate change [Music] you
